required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

detailed_description.textblock: ASUKI Step is a 9-month pedometer-based worksite intervention conducted at the Karolinska Institutet (KI) in Stockholm, Sweden and Arizona State University (ASU) in the greater Phoenix area, Arizona. ASUKI Step used a quasi-experimental design based on the theory of social support. Participants included 2,118 faculty, staff, and graduate students from ASU (n = 712) and KI (n = 1,406) who participated in teams of 3-4 persons. The intervention required participants to accumulate 10,000 steps each day for six months, with a 3-month follow-up period. Steps were recorded onto a study-specific website. Participants completed a website-delivered questionnaire four times to identify socio-demographic, health, psychosocial and environmental correlates of study participation. One person from each team at each university location was randomly selected to complete physical fitness testing to determine their anthropometric and cardiovascular health and to wear an accelerometer for one week. Incentives were given for compliance to the study protocol that included weekly raffles for participation prizes and a grand finale trip to Arizona or Sweden for teams with most days over 10,000 steps.

primary_outcome.measure: Percent of sample walking 10,000 steps per day on at least 100 days (3.5 months) during the trial period.
primary_outcome.time_frame: End of walking intervention at 6 months
primary_outcome.description: Tally of the participants recording 10,000 steps on their pedometer log for 100 days of the 6 month walking intervention.

secondary_outcome.measure: Changes in self-perceived health and stress level, sleep patterns, anthropometric measures and fitness.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: End of the 6 month walking study
secondary_outcome.description: Compare the measures between the first week and the last week of the 6-month intervention study

arm_group.description: Quasi-experimental design with one-group, post-test only

intervention.description: The intervention required participants to accumulate 10,000 steps each day for six months, with a 3-month follow-up period. Steps were recorded onto a study-specific website. Participants completed a website-delivered questionnaire four times to identify socio-demographic, health, psychosocial and environmental correlates of study participation. One person from each team at each university location was randomly selected to complete physical fitness testing to determine their anthropometric and cardiovascular health and to wear an accelerometer for one week.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Employed at Arizona State University (ASU)or the Karolinska Institute (KI)
- The ability to read, speak and understand English (ASU only)
- Not currently pregnant or lactating
- Free of physical problems that affect the ability to walk, and e) ages 18 and older
Exclusion Criteria:
- Inability to walk
- Not employed or a graduate student at ASU or the KI

facility.name: Arizona State University and Karolinska Institutet
